newsitem.title: JAPAN: Toshiba to develop chip to ease Internet access.
newsitem.headline: Toshiba to develop chip to ease Internet access.

text.p: Toshiba Corp said on Tuesday it plans to develop a chip that will make it easier to link various electronic products, including mobile phones, televisions and facsimile machines, to the Internet.
The firm said that it has licensed technology from iReady Corp of the United States that can be easily integrated with the functions of consumer electronics products.

"Incorporating this technology in electronics devices, such as mobile phones, for example, makes them Internet-ready at only a small incremental cost and gives users easy wireless access to the Internet for e-mail and other information," Toshiba said in a statement.
If installed in a facsimile machine, users would be able to directly fax information from the Internet through the fax machine, a Toshiba spokeswoman said.
It would be possible to view information and images from the Internet on televisions equipped with the chip, she said.

"This technology agreement allows Toshiba to move forward aggressively in development of a new generation of Internet-ready consumer electronics products," said Tadatoshi Minamikawa, general manager of Toshiba's LSI planning division.
Toshiba said it would develop the technology as the core of its application-specific integrated circuits (ASIC) products and introduce it to the world market.
Based in San Jose, California, iReady was founded in January 1996 as a provider of technology in the form of intellectual property.
